page.title: 04Foxhall Hospital, Kesgrave
page.content: It used to be called the Ipswich Sanatorium, founded as a memorial to King Edward VII and built in 1912. The original buildings and equipment cost about 16,000 Pounds, but the hospital was extended during the next twenty years. It was built for people suffering from tuberculosis, facing south with balconies, so that patients could get sunshine and fresh air. In 1948 the hospital was taken over by the National Health Service and became a home for Ukranians who had been prisoners in the Second World War. From 1960 to 1975 the hospital dealt with general chest conditions, not just tuberculosis. In 1975 the hospital was closed. From April 1980, for about a year, the hospital was used as a centre for Vietnamese Boat People from the Far East.
